normalised: Flying within India can be a breeze if you know what to expect. Here's a breakdown to help you navigate your first flight, focusing specifically on Indian airlines:

normalised: Firstly, booking is key. Websites like MakeMyTrip and Yatra often have deals, but always compare with the airline's official site, for example, Air India (airindia dot in) or IndiGo (goindigo dot in). Look for fares listed as rupees two thousand five hundred onwards, but remember that prices fluctuate wildly, especially during peak season like Diwali or summer holidays. Booking forty five days in advance is generally a good idea for domestic routes. Also, keep an eye out for sales like the SpiceJet's "Mega Monsoon Sale" they often run, offering tickets as low as rupee nine hundred ninety nine (excluding taxes).

normalised: Baggage allowance is crucial. Most domestic airlines like Vistara allow fifteen kilogram check-in baggage and seven kilogram cabin baggage. Exceeding this will result in extra charges, typically around rupees three hundred per kilogram. Dimensions matter too! Cabin baggage should usually be less than fifty five centimeter by thirty five centimeter by twenty five centimeter. Always double-check the specific airline's policy on their website before you travel. For example, Alliance Air sometimes has different rules, so confirming is vital.

normalised: At the airport, arrive at least two hours before departure for domestic flights, especially if you have check-in baggage. Security lines can be long, especially at major airports like Delhi (D-E-L) or Mumbai (B-O-M). Keep your I-D (Aadhaar card, P-A-N card, or Voter I-D) and ticket readily available. You can show a digital copy of your ticket, but a physical I-D is a must. Most airlines close check-in forty five minutes before departure, so don't be late!

normalised: Onboard, expect a mix of experiences. Some airlines, like Air India, offer complimentary meals on most flights. Others, like IndiGo, have a buy-on-board menu with options ranging from sandwiches to noodles. You can pre-book a meal online to save time and ensure availability. Remember to carry some change (rupees fifty or rupees one hundred notes) in case their card machines are down.
